awd_titl_txt: A database for an understudied language: A dictionary, grammar, and texts with sound
awd_abstract_narration:
The goals of this project are two-fold. First, the project focuses on further developing the infrastructure of an on-line database that includes a dictionary, a grammar, and texts of an endangered language. A dictionary, a grammar, and texts are considered to provide the basic material required for research on a language, and themselves involve considerable research. Second, the project further develops the content of the database, adding previously inaccessible materials, and in particular sound materials, to the database. 

This database will serve as a model for other on-line dictionaries, grammars, and texts. It will also be invaluable to those working on looking to understand the internal structure of the language family, and how the languages have developed over time, and the recordings included in it allow for the study of actual speech, an area of great importance in linguistics today. As a language from a family with complex verb structure, the database also provides rich material for its study, particularly in comparison with related languages, to understand how such complexities change over time and space. It also aids in the preservation of and access to materials that are irreplaceable today.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The Lenape or Delaware Indian language was once spoken in several dialects over an area of approximately 20,000 square miles in the area that now makes up all of New Jersey, northern Delaware, eastern Pennsylvania, and southeastern New York.  The Lenape people were pushed in multiple moves from the East Coast to Oklahoma. Unfortunately, people who grew up with Lenape as their first language are no longer with us but we do have extensive recordings made with those people.  There are a number of tribal members who are partial speakers and they have expressed a great interest in learning more of their ancestral language. Some of these people have learned to say prayers and give short talks in Lenape.

Funding from the National Science Foundation has enabled the creation and continued improvement of the Lenape Talking Dictionary. During this grant period we have been able to increase the number of entries in the form of single words and sentences, as well as stories in the Lenape language. The dictionary first went online in 2005 and we think it was the first online dictionary of a Native American language that had sound files.

One of the things we had planned to add to the dictionary were videos of people using the language. We had actually started work on creating these videos when the Covid virus appeared. That meant that it was no longer possible to have people get together to work on the videos but fortunately the ones that we had started on are now available on the Lenape Talking Dictionary. These include videos of our elder speakers telling stories and conversing as well as some of the younger partial speakers. These are also subtitled both in Lenape and in English for those who are learning the language.

In addition to the main Lenape Talking Dictionary in an effort to reach more people we have also created lists of Lenape words in categories. These are categories such as animals, birds, fish, houses, and so forth.  The lists contain not only the Lenape word but also the English translation as well as photographs of the subject of the list. Due to their size they are hosted on the Delaware tribal website at http://delawaretribe.org/blog/2013/06/26/language/.  There are links back to these lists from the dictionary as well as the subjects and addresses being published in the quarterly Delaware Indian News, the tribal newspaper.

Several new lists were recently posted and here is the list:  Lenape Names for the Arms and Body; Lenape Names for the Legs and Feet; Lenape Names of Internal Organs, and Lenape Names of Other Body Parts.  There are now about 45 lists available. 

We also produce Lenape Word-a-Day calendars.  The downloadable calendar is posted on the tribal website with the calendar for that month.  There are sound files for each of these words which can be found in the Lenape Talking Dictionary.

 


Last Modified: 01/03/2022
Modified by: James A Rementer
